The sun changes its rising and setting points on the horizon during the year in a cyclic pattern. Ancient people could use natural landmarks such as distant mountain peaks to take note of when the cycle repeats, and count the days. It’s not a big leap for humans to begin placing markers, like stones, to mark the rising or setting sun. Stone circles are quite common archaeological artefacts. Incidentally the best time of year to mark the rising or setting sun for counting days would be at the equinoxes, when the sun rises due east and sets due west. This is because the sun’s apparent north-south movement on the celestial sphere is greatest then, so its rising or setting point on the horizon changes most rapidly. It would then be easiest to pin it down to the exact day. Of course the fly in the ointment here is that if you’re nomadic you can’t do this.

In some ancient civilizations, the years were counted based on the ruler—a person was born, or a specific event happened in the third year of the reign of … Other civilizations had calendars that dated from early in their civilization—the Chinese, Persian, Hindu, Jewish, Roman, Ethiopian. The Muslim and Christian calendars displaced some of the older ones, and now some countries will use two ways of recording the years—the ubiquitous Western calendar and the “local” calendar tied to their own observances and celebrations.

The Chinese year system worked on a 60-year cycle. There are 10 heavenly stems and 12 earthly branches, and a combination of one each consecutively leads to 60 variations. For example, this year is the dingyou 丁酉 year, where ding is the heavenly stem and you is the earthly branch. As you may see, it is most useful for a person’s lifetime and less so for longer periods. As such we read documents in relation to the creator, for example when an artist signs with a year we know that it can only be a year he lived in. We also relate it to reigns. For example, the year 1898 is often expressed as “the wuxu 戊戌 year of the Guangxu reign”.
